citation.title: The Increasing Visibility of the Threat of Health Care Worker Self-contamination

news.title: Medical gown, glove removal often contaminates skin, clothing
news.summary: Florescent lotion and black light revealed that health care workers often contaminate their skin and clothing while removing their protective gear, researchers say.

news.title: Self-Contamination High Among Healthcare Workers
news.summary: Healthcare workers (HCWs) often contaminate their skin and clothing when removing contaminated gloves or gowns, according to a report and editorial published online October 12 in JAMA Internal Medicine.

news.title: Medical staff open to contamination because of gowns, gloves
news.summary: CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Medical staff is at greater risk for infection by pathogens than they should because of improper removal of gloves and gowns, according to simulations in a study conducted with hospital employees.

news.title: Study finds health care workers frequently contaminate their hands, clothing in removal of gloves, gowns
news.summary: Contamination of the skin and clothing of health care workers happened frequently during the removal of gloves or gowns in a simulation study published by JAMA Internal Medicine that used fluorescent lotion and black light.

blogs.title: Half of medical workers contaminate themselves when removing personal protective equipment
blogs.summary: Even when they don protective gear correctly, nearly half of medical workers contaminate their skin or clothing when removing gowns and especially gloves, a recent study published in JAMA Internal Medicine found.read more

Health Care Worker Self-contamination
